Showcase your arsenal with style!
Print this two part Nerf Strongarm Stand!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed this on a Makerbot 2 with low resolution settings in PLA.
Any printer with at least 100mm part height will work.
Tip: Print both parts at the same time and position them on opposite sides of the printer. Because of the extra time the extruder needs to get to the other part, the small structure on the top of the stand will have more time to cool down and the result will be better!

Software used

-Autodesk Inventor Student Version

description.text:
This is a quick mount I made to fit 2 ping sensors on the Tetrix building system. The ping sensors should be able attach without any screws. I made the holes tight enough so that they are held by pressure.

This print requires support
Print at 200 microns or better
Please use support
infill varies depending on your printer I had it at 20% but I think you can change it to whatever you please.

You may have to drill out the hole pattern due to shrinkage.

comments.text: were you ever really able to get the sensors to work? We have purchased two and have been struggling to get them to work!
comments.author: nguyenboys

comments.text: what control system are you using?
comments.author: nguyenboys

comments.text: This is awesome. We are looking into new sensors. What do you suggest?
comments.author: VCHSRobotics

comments.text: It depends really on the challenge. In general each year we use two main sensors which is the encoders and gyroscopes, but we since last year we switched over to an IMU (inertial measurement unit) which gives us more degrees of freedom and thus allowing us to have more control of the robot.. Then depending on the challenge we will add bumper switches or pots. The ping sensors are good more for detecting the distance between you and an object ahead. If the challenge does not require you to look for, or stay away from objects ping sensors you can do without. However you could use them to detect how far away from the wall so that your robot can automatically move to a more correct position. But in short the encoder and gyroscope is all you really need. Keep in mind I am from Canada and we don't have FTC here so I don't really know your challenge that well.
comments.author: VCHSRobotics

description.text:
These adjustable feet are designed to be installed on the bottom of a MakerBot for easy leveling. brought to you by:
www.tinkerdepot.com
[email protected]

Foot Assembly
-Break and clean out the rings supporting the bolt cavity in the bottom of the foot(round part) with a small flat head screw driver.
-From the bottom insert one #10 washer and the bolt.
-From the top insert another #10 washer and install the #10-32 nut and tighten. Receptacle Assembly
-Insert a #10-32 nut into the hex shaped cavity.
-Press fit the printed plastic ring to cover/retain the nut. Foot Assembly
-Insert foot into the side of the receptacle that has the retainer ring.
-Install the anti-skid pad.
-Use double sided tape to secure the to bottom of the TOM.

My first model EVER in the history of universe!
It turned out quite good, no big problems printing. Forza Ferrari - Forza Kimi!

I would redone this with smaller nozzle (0.4mm used, acetone bathed)
Be carefull when removing the lettering from the heatbed!

First of all I want to say thanks Gael Langevin who is the creator of the InMoov 3D-printed robot that I'm building.
You can find the original design on his site http://www.inmoov.fr.
This post is the first one in a series of changes that I have made to the head of the robot.
This post shows the parts that have been redesigned to make room for more electronics in the head. The outside is still the same as the original InMoov head. It's only the inside that has changed. Use the original InMoov head parts for everything that isn't in this post.
I use a smaller servo to turn the head than the original one.
The cogwheels have been removed and the jaw has been redesigned so that the jaw servo could be relocated.
The electronics I have in the head now is 2 standard size servos for the head turn and jaw, 3 smaller servos for the eyes,
a Raspberry PI 2 with a PI camera, an Arduino Uno, a USB sound card, an amplifier, a speaker and a USB transmitter for the keyboard and mouse.
On some of the pictures I have removed the connecting cables to make it easier to see how it's built.
On the pictures you can also see that I use a modified neck and a headstand. The eye's and the eye mechanism is also a new design.
Since this is work in progress and not all parts have been tested, I will publish them when they work.

Update 20150930. The jaws moved to slow, so I changed the threads to increase the speed. Use JawPistonV2.
Part 2 is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:994720

Update 20151206. I added HeadStandNeckHolder to this post. It's not necessary if you build the whole robot, but it can be used to hold the head on a stand without printing any of the rods. It's the part that sits under NeckJointUpper and is holding the head using cable straps, It can be seen in sevral of the pictures.

Updat 20160126. Added a few more pictures to show how things are mounted.

Update 20161030. If you don't like that the cables run outside the neck, this remix that dix23 made works very well, and is the part that I use now: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581955

Print one piece of each and one extra JawSupportV2.
To rebuild the neck to be able to mount a standard size servo use
NeckRedesignV5, LowBackRightV3 and LowBackLeftV3.
The NeckRedesignV5 is the part that all other pieces are mounted to.
The LowBackRightV3 needs and LowBackLeftV3 needs support structures. A good slicer can provide that. The large flat pieces are there to avoid making support structures.

To rebuild the Jaw, use parts JawV6, two JawSupportV2, JawHingeV3 and JawPistonV1. As you can see on the pictures the JawHingeV3s' are mounted under the NeckRedesignV5. The original has the jawhinges on the top.
The last piece SkullTopV5 is to hold the top of the skull togethers, since the original part is integrated with the big servoholder.
The NeckJointUpperV1 needs to be printed upside down, with support. The slicer I use has an option to only make support only under parts that are not touching the printbed. The purpose of the disc is to prevent building support structure in the middle.

The NeckJointUpperV1 fits with Neck_Joint_Lower_in_Millimeter the was created by RentaPrinter. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:861146/#files

OK
For the neck, i.e.to turn the head left and right I use Futaba S-148, but I will change it to a digital servo of the same size.
For the jaw, i.e. to open and close the mouth I use Futaba S3003, Both servos are the same size and they are what I refer to as "standard" size servos.
Then I use three micro/mini 9g servos to move the eyes. I use one to turn the eyes up and down, and one for each eye to turn left and right. I'm not at home now, so I don't know their exact name, but I can give you an update when I get home in a few days.

Okay. Good to know that I'm not alone anyway. Has the oversized printing caused issues in any other Inmoov parts that you can think of off-hand? I'm just getting started on my build, so I can potentially still avoid some wasted prints with this knowledge.

comments.author: monnerby

comments.text: Yes. I always scale 1% up to make sure that there is room for the servos. And I always scale down 1% on screws and cogwheels. It could be that PLA shrinks different that ABS, so that it's not needed. You should test to print a part that holds a servo, so that you know if you need to scale parts. The finger starter is a good start, since you can check with both a servo and an Arduino to see if it fits.

comments.text: Hi. I quote oldfarmhand who has built both the original and this head . "You get more room in the head due to smaller servos, smoother eye movement,smoother mouth movement, more room to put speakers and microphones, less parts in the neck due to no gears, overall just a lot more room to add other items". It's also cheaper to build, because of the smaller servo that is used. The original design doesn't have any computer in the head. The original design uses an external PC. comments.text: No, they work fine. But I never used the large scale servo, so I don't have anything to compare with. I have a feeling that the friction is lower without the cogwheels, so that less force is needed to turn the head. But if I would change anything, I would replace the neck servo with a digital one, They lock into position better than analogue. Oldfarmhand has built a new head for his robot based on this design and he wrote that the head movement is smoother after this change. You can find his comment on http://inmoov.fr/activity/ Look at the Community page.
comments.author: MoDiver888

description.text: This is a cover for a charger inlet on an electric vehicle.

Print it out.
I had intended to use o-rings to supply some sealing and friction but I didn't have any appropriately sized ones so I used some Sugru.
I spread it around on the inside (where the o-ring grooves are).
It didn't have to be very thick.
You could also modify the scad file to get it to work with o-rings if you have the right size.
There is a 4mm hole in the STL for a bolt to attach a tether.
You can disable it in the openscad if necessary.

Here's my first attempt at making a E3D V6 mount for my custom Ultimaker2.

To attach the two printed parts i've designed it to use 2 m3x10mm hex cap screws. The holes should be just small enough that the screws can self tap. So please don't over tighten.

Note this is a work in progress. I have several things I plan to add to the design this week, time permitting.

-Fan mount for printing with PLA

-Extend the top area upwards to help hide some of the loose wires.
-Add a clip at the top to help hold the wires in place.

Due to the placement of the hotend and the two m6 bearings I had to change the Ultimaker firmware slightly to adjust the Max X and Y.

X_MAX_POS 212

Y_MAX_POS 214

UPDATE 10-18-2015 - CAD files uploaded as requested by a few people. Please let me know if you have any trouble with them.

UPDATE 9-24-2015 - Added Version 1.4 files. This update adds the dual fan mount and the necessary M3 screw holes in the two pieces for the main E3D mount. Please note I would absolutely suggest using ABS for the fan mount. I've had good luck as long as temps are 235c or below. Also all screw holes are self tapping intended for M3 screws. Also for each fan I only needed to screw in the top two screws. The fit was tight enough that the bottom wasn't necessary. Also I added aluminum tape on the inside of the fan mount to help reflect the heat away from the ABS. I'm still not 100% sure how much it really helps. Just note i've slightly melted 2 fan mounts when running at 240c. Anyway, i'm not a CAD expert. So any suggestions/feedback is greatly appreciated.

UPDATE 8-06-2015 - Added V1.1 files. These have slightly smaller holes for bearings and the m3 screws. So both will be a tighter fit. So less play. FYI, If you're printer over extrudes circles you way want to use the original files instead.

title: Bellows / Shock Mount for Proton Pack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Here's an approximation of the bellows / "shock mount" that goes on the bumper of the proton pack from Ghostbusters. I based the shape generally on Stefan's plans, but modified to have 11 convolutions instead of 12 (as is visible in some photos of screen used packs) and a slightly longer length. It's 1.75 in long by 1.6 in OD with a 0.25 in ID mounting hole. I have no way of knowing how accurate these measurements are, but it's what looked good to my eye :) The example in the photo was printed on an Afinia H479, underwent acetone vapor smoothing (http://solidoodletips.wordpress.com/2012/11/10/presto-part-finisher/), and was painted with Krylon matte aluminum.
To minimize support material, print in the horizontal orientation as shown in the preview image.

title: Raspberry Pi print server base modified for Solidoodle

description.text: I got a RasPi running Octoprint to turn my Solidoodle into a networked 3D printer. I had already gotten rid of the spool holder for a new design, so I decided to use those four holes to mount the RasPi to the case. This design is a modified base half for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79036 (identical except for position of mounting tabs and holes). You can mount in either orientation.

• Print base from here.
  • Print top cover from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79036.
  • Remove spool holder bracket and mount case instead (same screws will work fine); you will likely need to clean/drill the holes a bit.
    • I would suggest putting some electrical tape on top of the interior screws to be safe (although the holes are sunk in, so clearance should be enough to avoid problems even with the original socket cap screws). Or you can skip those two screws entirely, or switch to pan-head ones. Also, the tabs are about 1-1.5mm thinner than the spool clip, so you could put standoffs between case and frame if you're worried about ventilation (seems just fine without, though). Tested with RasPi Rev. B. SCAD source file requires STL for original base from source thing in order to compile.

title: Vibration Dampening Raspberry Pi Camera Mount

description.text:
Simple vibration dampening mount for a Raspberry Pi camera module. The camera bracket is specifically designed for the generic 450 mm quadrotor frame I use, but should also fit a genuine DJI Flamewheel 450 mm and other varieties. Uses 4 paintball o-rings as support material, preferably the soft variety (duro 70).

The camera itself can be mounted with hot glue or foam mounting tape, I just had some tiny screws that worked. For the rest I used some small thread-forming screws I had on hand, 10 mm long M3 with Torx head. McMaster Part #96817a350 or equivalent. Or use whatever fastener works for you.

Adding weight to the mount seems to help also, YMMV. I used some stick on weights for pine derby cars.

Some youtube videos if you'd like to see the before and after:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3uSoHWvv_wI
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DAJWjFvBWu0

title: 4x4x6 Cuboid Twisty Puzzle

description.text:
The 4x4x6 cuboid was first built by Tony Fisher from a regular Rubik's 4x4x4 in 2004. Joshua Bell commissioned the design of an open source 4x4x6 design in 2011.
The design for this puzzle is really quite complex and the supplied STL files are probably only printable on high-end printers such as Shapeways' SLS printers. Nevertheless, I hope the SolidWorks file will still be useful to many for learning the art of puzzle design or making derived puzzles.

The parts provided in the STL files have a wall thickness of 0.7mm, so they can probably only be printed in Shapeways' WSF material or on some other high-end printers.
For your convenience, you can order a pack of all the parts required to build this puzzle at Shapeways: http://www.shapeways.com/model/291445/4x4x6_cuboid___open_source.html
To assemble the puzzle, you will need 6 M3 screws (4-40 machine screws might work as well) and some M3 springs (about 10mm long). Using some small washers is recommended, and applying some silicone lubricant will improve turning of the puzzle a lot.
Additionally, I can sell you an assembled copy of this puzzle. Contact me at [email protected] for this service. To open the SolidWorks file, SolidWorks 2011 or higher is required. I have tried to keep everything nicely organized in folders so the structure of the file is as clear as possible. A zip file containing all the STL files is supplied for easy downloading (it's right at the bottom of the list).

tags: rubik's cube puzzle 4x4x6 cuboid twisty 3d game

comments.text: The centers are made of two parts, a fixed "axle" part that is fixed to the core and cannot rotate with respect to it, and a second part (that actually forms the center) that can rotate around the axle. The reason for this is that the 4x4x6 has hidden internal layers, and the fixed axle part is needed to prevent the hidden layers from rotating.

description.text:
A three-sided generic coffee capsule holder. I needed a coffee capsule holder for my Portuguese Delta Q capsules and most of the models I could find were for Nespresso or Dolce Gusto, hence this design. It fits 12 capsules (4 per side) because that's the amount after which I need to remove the capsules from my machine. Capsule parameters and size can be changed on the beginning of the openscad file.

PS: this is also my first design, so feel free to comment and suggest improvements.

• Use openSCAD to open the cad file.
  • Adjust the capsule dimensions or the size of the holder at the top of the file.
  • Export the STL file.
  • Send it to the printer in the usual way.

author: garciamauro

description.text:
Crazy tall feet.  They add 30mm to the height before adding any foam.  If you really want to reduce noise, then be sure to add some self-adhesive foam.  I had some 3/8" thick soft silicone foam lying around that has worked out well to reduce noise and keep it from moving.  Silicone foam is not cheap, so I'm sure other types of foam would work quite well for a lot less $.  
My design was heavily influenced by Gijs' Ultifoot.  Those work great, but when I added a power supply and different fans to the bottom of my printer, I needed a lot more height.  I also wanted a larger base so the foam was not compressed so much, so I increased the footprint.

Requires:
(2) TallFoot
(2) TallFootMirror

title: Stratux ADS-B Raspberry Pi case. (Dual RTL-SDR/AHRS )

description.text:
edit: Unless you are using really old mini sized SDR's do not use this design

I highly recommend anyone who is not limited to a 6" print bed to make the long version of this case. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1016829 It works much better with SMA antennas as the MCX-SMA pigtails are attached to the case.

Three part case for the Open source Stratux ADS-B receiver for people with small 3d printers.

Supports dual RTL-SDR receivers. Remove the cases and use a small amount of hot glue to secure them to the middle layer. (Nov 6 increase thickness of this part to make space for GPS/AHRS pins)

Third layer holds the GPS/AHRS. (Sept 15 Increased thickness of this part to fit the GPS)

Added a version of the top case with recessed holes for the M3 bolts that hold it together.
Remove cases from RTL-SDR they fit tightly in and I use a tiny bead of hot glue to keep them from popping out. You will need a pair of short (6") USB extension cables.

I wanted a cool looking smoke extractor that worked, so I made one. It has a "wind tunnel" effect (or so it looks, and maybe works). There is a slot for a standard PC fan in the front, a gap, then room for the filter before expelling the air.
The control panel will change as I get better looking switches. I left room for an led to illuminate work, maybe adjustable, I don't know.
if you're still reading this, kudos.
The legs are adjustable, meaning you can cut what ever length you want. I used 18mm pipe.

Should I make the files available? or is this just dumb?
Hope you guys like it

title: Under table spool storage and holder #FilamentChallenge

description.text:
FilamentChallenge

Put a line of these under the edge of your work bench, and store your spools neatly out of the way and out of sight. When you are ready to use that spool, just pull out, pivot up, and push in to lock. The spool is ready to go. A built in filament guide keeps your filament from bird-nesting, and acts as an end holder when in the storage position. This holder will accommodate spools up to 3 inches wide by 9.5 inches in diameter. The guide hole is designed for 1.75 mm filament but can be drilled out for larger filaments.

You will need two screws for mounting the unit under the table, and you will need a 4-1/2 inch (115 mm) by 1/8 inch (3 mm) bolt and wing nut for holding the spool in place. I thought about making a completely printable solution, but sometimes metal hardware is just better.

I began designing this holder to use on my own workbench. However I have since moved my printer to another location where an overhead cabinet is a better solution. When I saw the new challenge it occurred to me that others might want to use my design, so I took some time and finished the drafting process. Since I will not be using it myself, I have not actually taken the time to print it. So, if there are any problems please let me know. Also, if you are an AutoCAD 2016 user and want a copy of the dwg file so you can make your own modifications I will be happy to send it.

author: mastertoa

description.text:
This is a printed connector shell for a near-Prologix-compatible GPIB to USB adapter project. It fits a 24-pin male GPIB connector and an Arduino Nano USB.
The Arduino GPIB code was written by Emanuele Girlando. All credit for this project goes to him.

To complete this project you will need:
Arduino Nano USB board (clones work fine) & Arduino IDE
Male GPIB connector (such as Cinch 57-10240)
Wire-wrap wire & tools
Four 4-40 x 3/4" screws & nuts for the shell halves
Two 2-56 x 3/8" screws & nuts to hold the GPIB connector into the shell
Arduino GPIB Software v6.1 (as of 8/2015) by Emanuele Girlando.

Complete use, wiring and testing details are on his Website, egirland.blogspot.com and click on the "GPIB" tag.
Or http://egirland.blogspot.com/2014/03/arduino-uno-as-usb-to-gpib-controller.html as of 8/31/2015.
Or search on GPIB USB Girlando if the link is bad.

Assembly:
The 4-40 holes might need a bit of reaming with a #34 drill bit depending on your printer's ooze factor.
I used 30% fill, raft and support with ABS. Top and bottom halves print simultaneously.
The 4-40x3/4" screws are a bit long. I filed them down a bit. 11/16" (!) would be ideal.
M3x16 would work fine with a bit more reaming.
The 2-56 nuts may be a tight fit into their slots depending, again, on your printer's ooze factor.
The adapter doesn't need the GPIB jack screws as it will plug right onto your instrument and weighs almost nothing.

title: Streamlined Spool Holder with Filament Guide

description.text:
Update 2:
-Added mini version without angled base: 30mm shorter than compact version and 6mm narrower, still works for standard-size spools

Update 1:
-Added 10mm shorter version with thinner+angled base
-Increased tolerances for connecting bar

This is a minimalistic, streamlined spool holder designed in a retro style that has an integrated filament guide, prints in only 2 pieces, and doesn't take a lot of material to print.

I designed this filament holder because I needed a more reliable way of feeding filament while printing but the existing designs I found either used too much plastic or needed additional components, like bearings and bolts. Because of this, my spool holder is designed with the KISS principle in mind, for lower cost and greater accessibility.

For standard and compact size:
Print 1 base.stl or base_compact.stl and 1 bar.stl.

For mini size:
Print 1 base_mini.stl and 1 bar_mini.stl.

If your spools of plastic have an unusually large diameter, print the compact or standard versions. The standard version looks better at larger layer heights due to the flat (non-angled) base.

The mini version is suitable for most spools with a ~200mm diameter.

I printed the spool holder with 1mm shells, 0.6mm top/bottom thickness, and 15% infill at a 0.2mm layer height. The bar was printed at the same settings except with 10% infill.
Print in the given orientation without supports. A print fan is recommended due to the overhangs in the model.

description.text:
Modified version of my original with a 20 degree offset to allow antenna or antenna extension to clear the Flight Controller. Mount is designed to attach to the frame pillars. Includes a cover for minimal protection, yet allows for easy access to the dip switch and cable attachments. The LED channel lights are are clearly visible for channel switching. The cover is attached with simple cable tie held in place by the base walls. The base also is open allowing the heat sink to breath. Zip tie hold all together. See original for more images.

Adapted from Emax Nighthawk to now do ZMR250... As I do not have a ZMR, tell me if this works on your quad. Is based off dimension someone game me for pillar distance of 31mm (on center).

Printed with minimum layer height of 0.2mm and 40% infill.

Print using supports.

author: anthonywob

description.text: These two bowls are duals of two different polyhedra called pentagonal icositetrahedra. One bowl is based on the dual of the pentagonal icositetrahedron described in thing:865284 - The Pentagonal Icositetrahedron and Cuprite. The second bowl is based on the snub cube which is the dual of the pentagonal icositetrahedron used to make the containers in thing:986913. OpenSCAD code is included. It contains some comments about these polyhedra and their duals. The image shows the two versions of the pentagonal icositetrahedra in front, and their duals, the bowls, at the back.
Both bowls have flat bottoms and are easily printed without support and with 0.3 mm layers. They can be scaled to make smaller bowls.

This keyring was designed because I really liked my older, larger Fidget Gear Keyring, but found that it was a bit too big to use as a day-to-day keyring.

This keyring features a similar design, but only uses two gears, and both are the smaller, 15T 15PCD gears.

Updated 22/06/16: added STL's of the 15T gear with larger centre bore based on feedback that the holes were too small. There are now centre bores of 5, 5.4, 5.75 and 6.5mm. My testing shows that 5.4 and 5.75 work the best depending on what printer you use.

Assemble the keychain using two 12mm m3 bolts and two m3 nuts.

For ease of turning, I also used a sharp 5mm drill to re-bore the gears at high speed to give a smooth surface inside the bore, and also used a scalpel to clean up the axle shafts from where printing the circular layers left small ridges.

title: Cobblebot End Stop Fine Tuner X or Z, Solid V Wheel, 2020 Rails

description.text:
I designed this bracket to fit on the X or Z gantry plate in such a way to make it easier to contact the X or Z end stop with or without a fine tuner. The fine tuner can be an M3 screw that goes into the small hole. It would need to be lined up with the X & Z end stops of course. The larger holes are for the regular spacer and eccentric spacer to fit into. The spacers will only go on one way so you may need to turn your gantry plate around if they are reversed. Otherwise, the holes may be tight but should work.

This thing may work on other gantry plates with the solid V wheels on 2020 rails. The thickness of the gantry plate in this thing is assumed to be 3,2mm.

Designed to work with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945800 or something similar.

I used the Meshmixer to create supports. I printed it with 0.1mm layers at a slow print speed (about an hour to print). The file with the supports have the supports with very narrow points and poles. I printed in PLA.

title: (Updated 10-Nov) Pi-Drive "Pisces" computer: 1TB Raspberry-Pi Linux PC/appliance...... without the hacker mess!

description.text:
NOTE: see UPDATE 10-Nov-15 in #2 below.

Goal: integrate mass storage (1TB) with Raspberry Pi to create a low-cost DIY Linux PC, private cloud, HDMI personal media player, surveillance server, etc. in an aesthetically compelling package suitable for use as a home/office appliance.

Ingredients:
(1) 3D prints of the two attached files. These were developed on a Makerbot 2 using default settings but no rafts or bridges. See UPDATE in #2 below.
(2) WD PiDrive 1TB kit: 1TB hard disk drive with power-delivery accessories designed for Raspberry Pi:
http://store.wdc.com/promo/96259700 (UK store)
UPDATE 10-Nov-15: this kit is being upgraded to include injection-molded versions of the Pisces enclosure and Pisces mount parts (item 1 above) and will also include item 3 below, all at a significantly discounted package price (US now, UK end Nov):
http://store.wdc.com/store/wdus/en_US/list/ThemeID.21986300/parentCategoryID.13092600/categoryID.70262300/Accessories/WD_PiDrive (US Store)
(3) Right-angle (270 degree) HDMI male-to-female connector, such as:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00S4IBH5M?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

Software: there are many free software solutions to create appliances with Pisces. Some sites to check out: raspberrypi.org, projpi.com, getsync.com, osmc.tv, instructables.com (search Raspberry Pi, HDD).

(1) Print the two files attached. The photos show the two printed parts made on a Makerbot 2 with default Makerware settings, except rafts turned off.
(2) Procure the WD PiDrive kit (see URL above)
(3) Obtain a Raspberry Pi 2 single-board computer
(4) Procure a right-angle 270 degree HDMI male-to-female adapter (see URL above)
(5) Attach Raspberry Pi and WD PiDrive to the Pisces mount part
(6) Attach accessories and cables as needed to the Raspberry Pi (e.g. USB/WiFi dongle, Ethernet cable, USB keyboard/mouse, etc.)
(7) insert the Pisces mount into the Pisces enclosure part

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7Fspd3QBUSN

have fun with it :)

• Place on thumb.

  • Read book.

  • Enjoy

In building a filament spool holder, I kept the following design principals in mind

1: You should be able to change spools without tools
2: Plastic should not rub on plastic
3: It should handle any width of spool with a 52mm internal diameter hole
4: Should take up minimal additional space (especially footprint) of the spool itself
5: Any non-plastic parts should be easily and cheaply purchased anyplace without having to mail-order anything
6: You should be able to position the spool to feed off of the right or left side, regardless of if the spool is non-symmetrical.

Non-Printed Materials Needed
3x - 608 Bearings (Standard Skateboard Bearing)
1x - M8 - 9cm Bolt
2x - M8 Washers
1x - M8 Wing Nut

The slight tilt of the head keeps the spool on the holder without need for any threaded core or additional parts or high-friction between the spool and the holder itself.

UPDATE 1: First print worked well, but the tolerances on the bolt head and bearing for the vertical riser where a bit too tight. Adjusted the SLT file to make the holes for each slightly larger (0.125mm) that should allow a much cleaner fit. Also, the wings on the core seemed a bit fragile, so I beefed them up (increased the thickness by 1mm) to hopefully provide better strength.

Printing this time at .3mm / 25% Infill (Full Honeycomb) with support (for the bolt-head hole with 4 Shells in ABS. Version 2 of the Core and Vertical Riser are posted up now.

Update 2: Re-printed the core at .2mm / 25% Infill (Full Honeycomb). Much lighter and stronger (especially the reel stop find) - Added picture comparing the first and second versions.

Bolt's head is glued into the socket in the top of the base riser. Bearings are pressed into both ends of the Core (one end in intended to stick out a few millimeters) and the hole at the top of the base riser (should also stick out 2 millimeters).

The base is pressure-fitted together (use some Acetone to bind the parts together).

Put a M8 washer on either side of the core to improve the ability of the bearings to move freely.

Hold the whole thing together with the M8 wing-nut. You can tighten to allow the device to spin as freely as you like. A little friction is fine to avoid unwinding as the machine pulls the filament.

Printed out at .3mm / 50% Infill with support (for the bolt-head hole with 4 Shells in ABS - Will post up pictures after final all-on-one bed print.

remixed_from.title: Arduino Mega 2560 r3 bracket for Extrusions I-Type 5 slot - Horizontal version

title: Arduino Mega 2560 r3 bracket for Extrusions I-Type 5 slot - Vertical version

description.text:
I created my "Arduino Mega 2560 r3 bracket for Extrusions I-Type 5 slot." at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:989845 and originalle started designing this vertical version.

I went to horizontal version early in the designstage, but finished this one, as I bet some people would like it oriented like this.

Added Photos from my Horizontal Mount to show how the plastic-zipties Works - you do have to reorient them a tad though, but I'm sure you can figure it out.
There is no room to use actual screws for those two holes.

I printed 0.2 layer height and 20% infill. Plenty strong.

You can print either the 1-piece model, which doesn't have the connecting braces in the middle, or print the 2-pieces bracket.

You need 2 plastic-zippers for the two top holes (see photos, on how to orient them) and 2 M3 8mm screws. I used hexagon socket screws.

BOM
2x M3 8mm hexagon socket screws.

Here is the latest and most likely final fan bracket for the M2 Im going to produce.  
Complete re-design from the first two, added curved mounts for no obstruction of air flow and instead of mounting with one extruder bolt took advantage of the 2 holes on the bottom of the extruder.  
Offset the 50mm fan as everyone requested further to the right.  
Found it easiest to bolt on the 50mm fan to the bracket first then add the two 3mm standard nuts into the slots provided on the extruder hot end. Attached the bracket with two M3x16mm bolts being careful the bolts went into the nuts straight. Mounted the extruder hot end with the now fan bracket and 50mm fan to the extruder motor. Plugged back the wiring and then attached the 40mm fan.  
No jiggle or vibration as the holes are 3mm so nice and tight, will most likely need to screw the bolt all the way but this was intended.  
ADDED: For those who use the the right 2 stop holes and get really close to the frame I added m2fanbracketv3right  
Enjoy

title: Kuro´s Compact Extruder for the Diamond Hotend

description.text:
We found this extruder to be very usefull for the Diamond Hotend, as it will need additional extruding force, especially for the 3mm filament version.

We have remixed this extruder to include a 3/8" Push-in bowden mount and changed it to the 3mm filament.
You can recompile it for the 1.75mm filament, but when setup as 3mm filament you can still use it for 1.75mm filament.

I have provided the SCAD files for others to remix.

Complete kit can be bought here:
http://reprap.me/geared-extruder-kit.html

Printed Parts (minimum)

  • Extruder body
  • Idler
  • Gears

Hardware (minimum)

  • 2 springs for idler tension 4.8mm
  • 3 625zz bearings
  • 1 MK7 drive gear
  • 1 M5x40mm hex headed bolt
  • 2 M5 nuts
  • 2 M5 washers
  • 1 M5x20mm bolt
  • 2 M3x30mm bolts
  • 3 M3x20mm bolts
  • 5 M3x10mm bolts
  • 3 M3 square nut
  • 3 M3 nut

title: OAR Kit Wheels - laser cutting files

description.text: The files here include 4 different types of wheel. Two are an overall diameter of 95mm and the other two are based on a diameter of 120mm. All designs include mounting holes that match with the output of the Dynamixel AX-12A servomotor.

They are intended to be cut from a billet using a laser cutter. I have cut versions of these wheels in 3mm and 6mm material, both acrylic and MDF. All are intended to be assembled in two or three laminated layers, fixed together with a 5mm machine screw.

Note: That in each set, one of the fixing holes has been sized at 4mm. It can then be tapped out to fit the 5mm machine screw. If it were cut out to 4.5mm, it would probably screw straight in, like a Nyloc nut.

author: Anthonylu

description.text:
Many people who built the beta version of the Printrbot Simple have experienced a sag in the Y axis, causing the print bed to be way off level. This upgrade takes care of that completely on my printer, and hopefully on your printer as well.  
It fixes the problem in two ways. First, it provides a very secure, curved slot for the bearings, which helps keep them lined up. And second, it has a built-in 1.5 degree slope to counteract the sag.

There are two parts: a wedge and the bearing block. Print out two copies of each (one for the top bearings and one for the bottom).  
Remove the zip ties just from the top and place the first bearing block into the laser-cut slot. It can go in only one way because there is a cut-out for the screw used to hold the laser-cut part that holds the Z nut. Next place the wedge in from the back and push it firmly in place. Finally, add the zip ties, but don't tighten them completey yet.  
Now do the same for the bottom bearings. Once you have the blocks and wedges installed for both the top and bottom, tighten and trip the zip ties.  
Re-level your print bed and you should be all set to go.
A special thanks to twistedmedium on PrintrbotTalk who had a much simpler idea that I ran with. Here is the Fixing Sagging Y thread on PrintbotTalk.
I printed the bearing block using Kisslicer with support material, as you can see in some of the photos. I like Kisslicer because the support material is very easy to remove.

comments.text: Thanks for making this.  I installed a pair on my Printrbot Simple 1405. Similar to gregrob I trimmed out one of pieces to make room for the new location of one of the screw head.  I also have to offset the bearings and gear for the Y-axis belt.  I did that by replacing the screws with longer ones and adding a few washers to create the offset.  I have slightly longer zip ties and they worked well.  I also changed the bed to allow for manual leveling.  Printed out a pretty fine looking test cube.
comments.author: MirandaLam

comments.text: I just installed a pair of these last night on my Printrbot Simple 1405, and it works great!  My first test print afterwards was very much closer to orthogonal than anything I had previously obtained.  To make it work I shifted the belt gear on the Y motor shaft so it sits at the end of the shaft instead of inset by 2mm.  I also moved the outside washers on the belt tension bearings to the inside to shift the bearings keeping them in line with the belt gear.  The last stumbling block was with the top guide, there is a bolt head in the way of it sitting flush, I just nibbled away at the piece with a side cutter until I had made a cavity of sufficient size to accommodate the bolt head.  This bolt must have shifted slightly from the previous Printrbot design as the existing cutout on the part was almost in the right place.  Putting it all together required daisy chaining tie-wraps together, but if you have longer ones available that would of course be fine.

comments.text:
Just tried installing this with my Printrbot Simple 2014. Would have worked great if I didn't install Jon Lawrence's GT2 Y-axis upgrade (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194586)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... Since these blocks push the Y-carriage about 6.5mm away from the Y motor, the 608 bearings end up bottoming out on the carriage.
Kind of hard to explain, but beware that if you've installed the GT2 upgrade you cannot add these. Otherwise these look like a great way to eliminate sag.

description.text:
This is a magnetic mounted openframe viewfinder for the baby bessa.

My baby bessa had a broken viewfinder so ....seeing this one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:363857) I decided to do one for my camera !

You have two viewfinders :

  • for 6x6 negative
  • for a 24x60 (using a 135film)

It uses a magnet of 5mm diameter and 2mm depth for mounting on the bessa.

I haven't tested the accuracy with a film, but with ground glass it seems ok (be sure to align it correctly)!

PS : thanks a lot to schlem for the help !

• Rotate & Print (no support)
  • Put magnet (tight fit ...or glue if need). Be sure to have the magnet flat
  • Put it on the camera when needed !

This is a MudClaw for a Truvativ Hammerschmidt Crank Set.
I designed it with FreeCAD and added two files in .fcstd format if anyone wants to change anything.
I printed a couple of these with my M3D Micro in Low Fill Density and Low Quality and a test version with Hollow Thick Walls in Low Quality. Both versions survived over 200 km in quite rough terrain and still do their job nicely.

I hope you like it as much as I do. Have fun and keep on riding!
For mounting you will need to get M3 screws, which you will have to shorten to around 7 mm. If you print in Low Quality, like I did, you might need to drill out the screw holes.

Just for fun I made a crash cage for my mini UDI quadcopter. It came with its own body, but I felt like personalizing mine. It might add a bit of weight, but it still flies well and looks pretty cool doing it!
The cage snaps together, no glue or hardware required. Some light sanding might be necessary as the parts are small and machine tolerances vary.

Fly at night by using the GoPro/etc mount system to mount one or two headlights! The top of the model showing in the second picture above faces rearward, while the two long rails slide up into the plates of the mount system.

The Streamlight TRL-1 HPL is what's showing here but it does have a very narrow beam. Most any picatinny rail mount lights should work, as long as its reflector clears the landing skid.

You'll probably want to print this with Support, for the rail key holes. If you don't have access to a 3D printer, Shapeways will print it for you here.

title: INNOVATIVE Universal WALL Spool Holder (with Suction Cups)

description.text:
____I apologize for not being able to print all parts of this project , unfortunately my printer had problems in printing the file 4 v1 , as you can see in the picture , because the filament, I will try to print all of the parties as soon as possible_____

_____WHY I WANTED TO DESIGN THIS TYPE SPOOL HOLDER

This spool holder will allow you to position your filament position and preferred height .

Thanks to this innovative system you can place your spool holder where you want without problems.

I decided to design this spool holder because very often it is difficult to find the space to place the spool on top of the printer .
Therefore I decided to use 5 suckers, to be placed on the back of the spool holder, that allow to attack your spool where you want on any surface .

The spool holder also includes a guide to the 3mm and 1.75mm filament, wich you can move based on where you place the spool .

I decided to design also another version that, in place of the suction suckers, use a guide wedge for positioning the holder filament easily removable .

The second version is designed for those who know where to put the spool without moving more , and wants to make holes in the wall ( for example) to securely fasten it with screws .

On the following links you can find the few pieces needed to buy for the project

____PARTS REQUIRED

Shielded Ball Bearing (x2)

http://www.ebay.com/itm/2pcs-6202-2Z-ZZ-6202zz-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearings-15-x-35-x-11mm-/370644291087?hash=item564c1f0e0f

suckers ( x4 or x5 if you want )

http://www.ebay.it/itm/Ventosa-Ventose-per-Vetri-Cristalli-Trasparente-Misura-30-mm-conf-100-Pz-/331020580980?hash=item4d125d3874

or

http://www.ebay.it/itm/71644-cf-10-pz-di-ventosa-ventose-ventosine-trasparenti-per-vetro-con-sfera-/191592881237?hash=item2c9bd35c55

____PRINTING

All files were printed in PLA at 25% infill, with two shells at 0.26mm layer height (only the file nemed 3 need support material).

____ASSEMBLY

First you have to choose which version you want to use the wire holder . Both versions 1-2-3 files do not change , for version 1 you need to download more file called v1 , while the version 2 are needed files named v2 .
( the difference between the version one and two is that the first co fixed on any wall your reggi filament with 4 or 5 suction cups , while with the version du reggi the wire is wedged in an additional piece , fixed to the wall with screws 4 )

Once the files are downloaded and printed as desired follow these instructions consist of three steps: 

    _____ STEP 1

SPOOL HOLDER v1:

Place 4 or 5 cups in the holes 8mm seats at the back of the piece called "4 v1" and gaze at them with 4 M3 screws that are screwed into the four holes in the side.
On the pin present on the workpiece positioned at a distance of 5mm from the first plastic ball bearing

SPOOL HOLDER v2:

Place your piece called "5v2" with the 4 screws where you like.
After take the piece called "4v2" and positioned on the pin of 15mm present at a distance of 5 mm from the plastic the first ball bearing. 

   ______ STEP 2

(This step applies to both versions)

positioned as shown the second ball bearing in the groove in the conical part of the file "1" and insert the bearing pin in the file "or 4V1 4v2" by joining at the same time the outside of the first bearing in the groove of the piece "1 ".

Now if you followed all the steps correctly the piece "1" should rotate freely in the pin where it was located the first bearing. 

    _____ STEP 3

In this last step you just have to place the spool into the worm's file with one locking nut printed (file 2).
After placing the spool and the spool holder you just have to believe the place where megio guide the filament (file n3) as shown in the figure, one of several holes.
You can place a Teflon tube of about 10 cm into the groove of the file 3 uprising veerso the spool.
You can also lubricate or clean the filament inserting into the groove of the rectangular file 3 a piece of sponge.

__ PERSONAL ADVICE

I think it is best to place the spool on the wall with suction cups in a higher position than the printer , and therefore include it called 3 in the fourth groove ( fourth slot from the top) in the file 4 v1 or 4v2 .
It would also be appropriate to include the piece of sponge and the Teflon tube into the grooves in the file 3

comments.text: How do I print the top? There is no part to lay flat. Would be a bit easier if you made the gopro mount an attachment (with C.A.) so that the top can be laid flat. I ditto the comment by scratchymaster about cracking in a crash. For this reason I use aluminium verticals with ABS frames. Nice design though.
comments.author: anansi22

comments.text: If the holes in the upper frame are tolerance well, it shouldn't require a tap. How does that upper frame fare in a crash? I haven't had much luck printing structural posts vertically; cracks easily form between layers.
comments.author: scratchymaster

comments.text: Tolerance of holes are enough to tighten the screws. You don't need M3 tap actually.  Tighten the srew carefully with a little force is enough. Every 3D printout has a same problem,  unfortunately cracks easily.

description.text:
This stackable spool holder is designed to store spools from SMALL to XL size.
You can print only the base and store 2 SMALL or LARGE spools or 1 XL spool. Or you can print multiple levels and stack them to store 1 LARGE or SMALL spool on each level.

FilamentChallenge

To make a simple level spool holder you need the spool_holder_base_L and spool_holder_base_R and spool_holder_rod files.
For each additional level you need the spool_holder_stack_L and spool_holder_stack_R and spool_holder_rod files.
